ihruugh screenes of dowsy mist his smiles receive,

And shows the moving scene in purple hue;
The mountain glmmers through the prospect dim,

NOTiCE.

In respect to the lesser morals, all savages in this
region are hospitabe Even the enemy. whom they
would have sought and slain, far from the cabins.
who presents himself carelessly there claims and re-
ceives their hospitality. They accord to the cabin
hearth the in,olahty of an asylum, and the honors
and the sanctuary of an altar. A great number OF
instances record. of savages of hostile tribes
obnoxious to the most deadly revenge of particul
warriors. presenting themselves sudden before
those warriors. and opening their offered bosom TO
the knife. This undaunted heroism often disarms
not only the purpose of revenge. but, with deep
savage admiration. exctes more generous feelings.
and brings about a reconciliation and permanent
peace between the contendng tribes. That part
,f our character which they are the last to under
stand and least prone to admire. that when our
People have received in their villages lavish and
gratui'ous hospitality. they, when returning the visit.
should find that, with us strangers are lodged in
tayerns.


We have. by no means the same penarv faith in
that tenacious remembrance of kindness. which
historians have almost universally ascribed to them.
as trait nobly distinguishing them from other races.
We entertain very little reliance upon the conss
tencv of their friendship We consider them trea-
cherous and tickle in the extreme early swaye'l
from the views and purposes Of yesterday. and con
santy disposed to pay their court to the divinity Of
good fortune. and always ready to side with the
strongest Were we in their power. and fortune,
in reference to us, changing. we should make NJ
calculations for the morrow, upon their views and
purposes towards us to dav.


$ They are we'll known for their voraciousness o
I appetite. They endure hunger and thirst. as they
e do suffering, pain. and death, with astonishing pa
tlence and constancy. When they kill deer.
bear, or buffalo, alter long abstinence, they will
devour an enormous quantity of the flesh Thei
: devoted and fatal attachment to ardent spirits is
matter of melancholy notoricty. In all their coun
. cs, talks, conferences with the officers of our Gov
ernment from Lake Erie to the Rocky Mountains
their first and last request is whskey. The feel
ings of honor and shame be reached, in an lntia
bosom, upon every other point but this. Declan
. as we may against the of it, paint the i'll effect
of ii as strongly as we choose, speak with as muci
contempt may of drunkards, their best ant
bravest still clamor for whiskey


Al All words would be thrown away in attempting II
d pourtray, in just colours, the effects of genera
l. drunkenness upon such "A race. 1t is, indeed th
f. heaviest curse which their intercourse with th
whites has entailed upon them. Every obligation 0
duty, as philanhropsts and Christians, imposes up
on US every effort to prevent the complete and ina
expiration of this i'll tated race the inevitable con
sequence Of their being allowed free access to TIN
liquid poison of whiskey. We have elsewhere ad
verted to the stern and rigorous prohibitions OF th
Government, and the apparent fidelity with whlcl
these prohibitions carried into effect. And yet
in some way OF ether, wherever Americans hay
access, Indians have whiskey. 1t is understood
that the laws of the State Governments and thu
General Government are not exactly in coincidence
and concert upon the. subject of ntericting spirit
to the Indians This state Of things ought not tt
exist. 1t is fact of common notorlety, that IN thu
), States, they find much less difficulty, in procuring
), whskey than in the Territories. The duties ofth'
e States imperiousy bind them to frame laws, and tt
sec them executed, in unison with the seyerest in
1t terctions of the General Government, and to unt
with that to prevent these unhappy beings from ex
cercsing their suicidal propensities.


1t has been Inferred, because they make it pon
not to express establishment or curiosity in view o
d our improvements and arts, that they are destitute
ST of the feelings of curiosity and because the,
e seem to hold them in contempt and disdan, tina


they have no passion analogous to the cupidity
From the Western RepieV.
SKETCH OF INDIAN CHARACTER.

broken into small jerky fragments Of sound, by pas
sing their hand by rapid motion across their lips.


This is the most characteristic of all Indian noises.
1t seems easy to initiate and yet we have heard Ame-
ricans personate every part Of an Indian dance with
better and closer mimicry than this. They have
the war. the feast, the scalp, and the big dance.
and perhaps others. and tunes corresponding to the
different purposes Of these dances. IL our ear, these
tunes are exceedingly monotonous and uniform, rum
ming only thro three four notes, and constantly
recurring to the strain. The last note OF this
strain is to us terrible when heard we have often
heard it by wight, ringing through the woods. The
song, like the dance, breaks off by that broken yell
which they make by the rapid motion of their hand
over their mouths. In most of the tribes, the wo~
men take no part in the song. We remember only
to have heard the women of the Sacs and Foxesjnin
in the song; and they did it by Ginning in couple
or three sharp notes, with strong nasal twang at
the last part of the tune.

M people can generate the emphatic and character
lstlc sneer OF pride quicker, more strongly, on
their countenances. 1t is their pride that induces
them to affect this Indifference for that it is affect
ed we had numberless opportunities to discover. 1t
is with them not only pride, but calculation, to hold
In seeming contempt things which they are aware
they cannot obtain and possess.


As regards their vanity, and that part of the
species upon which it is supposed to operate with
more force, we have not often had the fortune to
contemplate young squaw at her toilette. But
IRON the studied arrangement of their calico jacket;
from the glaring circles of vernillon on her plump
and circular face from the artificial manner in
which her hair Of intense black, is dubbed in roll
OF the thickness of mans wrist from the loBg
time which 1t takes her to complete these arrange
ments, from the manner in which she minces, and
anbles and pays of her prettiest airs, after she has
put on all her charmswe should clearly infer that
dress and personal ornaments occupy the same por-
ton OF her thoughts that they do of the fashionable
women of civilized society,"


young Indian warrior is VIGOROUSLY the most
thorough going heau in the world. Bond street and
Broadway furnish no subjects that will undergo as
much crimpng and confinement to appear in full
dress. We are confident that have observed
such character constantly occupied with his paints
and his pocket glass full three hours, ying on his
colours, and arranging his tresses, and contemplate
ing from time to time with visible satisfaction, the
progress of his growing attractions. When he has
finished, the proud triumph of irresistible charms
| is IN his eye.-The chiefs and warriors in full
dress, have one, two, or three broad clasps OF
silver abUnt their arms generally jewels in their


ears, and often in their nose, and nothing is more


common than to see thin circular piece of silver,


the size of dollar, depending from their noses, IA


little below their upper lip. Thi- ornament, so


painfully nconyenent, as it is evidently to them.
and otr TO ho nj


most finish of In an taste Painted Porcupine quilts


ire twisted in their hair. Tails of Animals hang


from their hair behind, or from the point where they


we're originally appended to the animal. A necklace


of bears alhgaor's teeth, OF claws of the bale
eagle, hang loosely down, and interior and small
circle OF large red beads, or, in default of them
!. 4 rosary OF reu hawthorns surrounds the neck
From the knees to the feet the legs ornanente


with great numbers Of little perforated cylindrical
n pieces of silver or brass, that emit smultaneou
tinke. as the person walks. If to all this he adj
an American hat, and soldiers coat of blue, f,ce
with red over the customary calico shirt, of tn.


gaudest colours that be found, he lifts his fee
i high, and steps firmly on the ground, TO give hi
i tinkers an uniform and full sound, and apparent!
: considers his person with much conplacency a
II the human bosom can be supposed to feel. This
e IA very curiaIed view of an Indian beau. But ever
, reader, competent to Judge, will admit in fidelity,





q warrior over the whole Mississippi valley, whe
prepared to take part in public dance.


y Strange as it may seem to our Atlantic readers
the sight Of such an Indian is almost'a, rare spec
= tacle in this city CCncinnat as in Philadelphia
:, i}nston.--But so many faithful prints of India
:, figures and costume have recently been presented
y the public that most of those who have tn


wing subject. have the deinltive views Of the get
~ era outlines of Indian appearance. The males a
most UNIVERSAL wear lcggins in two distinct piece
> ike the legs of pantaoons, fitted very tight fro
Il the lpins to the ancles generally Of smoke tanne
IN deerskin and scanned witt tassels or leather fringe
~ sometimes of blue cloth. Those who inhabit ii
Is regions beyond the range of the buffalo. ba,
~ ket, thrown loosely their shou uders; and thos
ID who live in the region of that animal, its dres


ed skin in the same way. Their moccasons are o.
~ namented, with extreme care. with different coln
al ed porcupine quilts, arranged in lines and compar
le ments. But, in the sulry months, they are ofte
ie seen with other dress than piece cf blue cloti
OF in the language of the country 'stroudng, passe
p between the thighs, and brought round the loins.
al In regions contiguous to the whites. they have ge,
n orally calico shirt, of the finest colors; and the
he are particularly attached to long calico dress, n
d. sembng morning gown.


ne The women wear calico Jacket. legsins M
- much unlike those Of the men. and whenever the
- can afford it blee broad cloth petticoat made ful


ana Dunchlng our, as II SWelleN WIN hoo!' w
'a do not remember to have Indians. either nal

e The thick, heavy black tresses Of hair are parte
is from the centre of the forehead and crown, an
to skewered with quill thorn, in large club b,
ie hind.


lg They have various dances. to which they seem e'
he travaganlv attached. and which often have, as di
to the dances of old time religious c!.aracter fh
n aged comc chiefs drum, with intarablc gravity
apI ttn w
K great vehcn,ence, pounding their feet upon til

WEST OF THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS.


We have been politely favored by Gen. CLAnxs
of Indian Affairs. with the pernsa OF
a letter, written by Jedediah S Smith, who has been
for several years engaged 10 hunting and trapping
in the Upper Missouri. and who has visited that ex-
tcn.ve barren country OH the West. not here otore
explored. From this letter. written IN plain stylx.
we extract the following. which, trust, will be
found interesting to our readers.


Missouri Republican.


Ny situation has enabled me to collect information
respecting country which has been. measurably.
yelled in obscury. and unknown to the citizens OF
the Unite States. | allude to the country South
Westof the Great Salt Lake, land West Of the Rocky
mountains.


About the 22d of August, 1896. left the great
Salt Lake. accompanied with party of fifteen men,
for the purpose ofexploring the country to the Sout.
West which was then entirely unknown to me- and
of which could obtain satisfactory information.
from the Indians who inhabt the country on its North
East borders. My general course on leaving the
Lake, was S. W. and w. passing the Little Uta
Lake, and ascending Ashey's River. which empties
into it, where we found nation OF Indians, calling
themselves Sumpdch. who were friendly disposed
towards Us. After leaving the Little Uta Lake,
found no further sign Of ,nFalo-here were. howe
yer. few Of the Anteune and Mountain shees, ana
all abundance OF Black Tailed Hares. Leaving
| Ashe,'s River. | passed over range Of mountains.
s. f. and N. ". and struck river, running $. W
which named Adams River. in compliment TO our
| President. The water of t',s river is OF muddy
cast, and somewhat brackish. TIE country is noun
famous to the East, and IN the West arc detach-
ed rocky hills and sandy plains Passing down
this river some distance. fell in with nation ot
Indians, calling themselves Pd Utches. These In
dans. as well as the Sumpatch, robes made Of
rabbit skins; they raise and pumpkins on which
they principally subsst-except few hares, very


little game of any description is to be found About
ten days march further down, the river turns to this
5 Il. where, on the S. w Of it. there is il remas-
kable cave. the entrance to which about ten or hf-
teen feet high and five or six feet in width after
descending about fifteen feet, opens into large and
spacious room, with the roof, walls, and tloor OF
solid rock salt "a niece of which send you, will,
some other articles which will be hereafter descrlb-
ed followed Adams river two days travel fur
ther, where emp,es into the Seeds Keeder. which
| crossed and went a south course down it, through
(, barren, rocky. and mountainous country. La tS
river are manv shoals and rapids. Further down. Il
valley opens. from five to fifteen miles in width. The
land on the river bank is fertile and timbretl. here


found another tribe of Indians. who call themselves
Amnuchcbes. They cultivate the soil, and raise
, corn. beans. pumpkins and melons in abundance,
and also a little wheat and cotton | was now
nearly destitute of horses, and had learned what it
was to do without food therefore concluded to
remain here fifteen days. to recruit my men and IN
the mean time, succeeded in changing my few re-
naming horses, and was enabled purchase others.
| from il party Of runaway Indians. who had stolen
them from the Spanards | here obtained some
information respecting the Spanish country. OBJ.
, tanned two guides recrossed the Seeds keedcr,
and travelled West course fifteen DAYS. over Il
country of complete barrens, and frequently Iron,
morning until night without water. Crossed salt
, plain eight miles wide and twenty long. On the
surface of the ground is crust OF white salt, un-
derneath is layer of yellow sand, and beneath the
sand few inches, the salt again appears The ri-
yer Seeds Keeder have since learned, empties it.
self into the Gufof California. about 80 miles from
the Aminuchehes. and is there called the Colorado


On my arrival in the province of Upper Califor-
mia, was eyed with suspicion, and was compelled.
10 appear in the presence of the Governor, residing


at ST. Diego, from whence, BY the assistance OF some
American gentlemen, (particularly Capt W. II.
Il Cunningham, of the ship Courier, from boston,1 1
ssns euabled to obtain permission TO return with my
men, by the route had come. also obtained
permission TO purchase such supplies as stood IN
need Of. AS the Governor would not permit me
10 travel up the sea coast towards Bodago, pao-
ceeded eastward of the Spanish settlement. then
, turned my course N. W. keeping from so to eco
, miles from the sen coast travelled three hun
, Idred miles in this direction, through country

Containing IN addition to the usual astronomer
Calculations. Tables. &c. the Courts of the United
States, and of Delaware and Maryland great va
r'ey OF profitable and pleasing miscellaneous mat
ter. among which is


Sailors humorous ride in milk-cart,
fankey resolution in saving the mail,
ingenious defence of thief,
Dreams and signs interpreted
Method of un-marryng the unhappy,
Definition ofa Drunkard,
a little world
Old maids, their unmeutionabe troubles,
Account of novel courtship,
Anecdote of Paddy and his game cock,
The lrishman. and his pig. Sc. &c &c.
Wonderful discoveries of the Microscope,


Humorous account of a Penna. Battalion Day,


nmashngtons arnA saved by Quaker lady.


Ode to the gout,


RECEIPTS for curing the Gravel, curing Wens,
making candies, removing grease spots from clothes,
making vinegar, preserving pickles, preserving
meats, sc. &c. sc.

duty, as philanhropsts and Christians, imposes up

expiration of this i'll tated race the inevitable con
sequence Of their being allowed free access to TIN
liquid poison of whiskey. We have elsewhere ad
verted to the stern and rigorous prohibitions OF th
Government, and the apparent fidelity with whlcl
these prohibitions carried into effect. And yet
in some way OF ether, wherever Americans hay
access, Indians have whiskey. 1t is understood
that the laws of the State Governments and thu
General Government are not exactly in coincidence
and concert upon the. subject of ntericting spirit
to the Indians This state Of things ought not tt
exist. 1t is fact of common notorlety, that IN thu
), States, they find much less difficulty, in procuring
), whskey than in the Territories. The duties ofth'
e States imperiousy bind them to frame laws, and tt
sec them executed, in unison with the seyerest in
1t terctions of the General Government, and to unt
with that to prevent these unhappy beings from ex
cercsing their suicidal propensities.

full articles.article:
broken into small jerky fragments Of sound, by pas
sing their hand by rapid motion across their lips.


This is the most characteristic of all Indian noises.
1t seems easy to initiate and yet we have heard Ame-
ricans personate every part Of an Indian dance with
better and closer mimicry than this. They have
the war. the feast, the scalp, and the big dance.
and perhaps others. and tunes corresponding to the
different purposes Of these dances. IL our ear, these
tunes are exceedingly monotonous and uniform, rum
ming only thro three four notes, and constantly
recurring to the strain. The last note OF this
strain is to us terrible when heard we have often
heard it by wight, ringing through the woods. The
song, like the dance, breaks off by that broken yell
which they make by the rapid motion of their hand
over their mouths. In most of the tribes, the wo~
men take no part in the song. We remember only
to have heard the women of the Sacs and Foxesjnin
in the song; and they did it by Ginning in couple
or three sharp notes, with strong nasal twang at
the last part of the tune.

M people can generate the emphatic and character
lstlc sneer OF pride quicker, more strongly, on
their countenances. 1t is their pride that induces
them to affect this Indifference for that it is affect
ed we had numberless opportunities to discover. 1t
is with them not only pride, but calculation, to hold
In seeming contempt things which they are aware
they cannot obtain and possess.


As regards their vanity, and that part of the
species upon which it is supposed to operate with
more force, we have not often had the fortune to
contemplate young squaw at her toilette. But
IRON the studied arrangement of their calico jacket;
from the glaring circles of vernillon on her plump
and circular face from the artificial manner in
which her hair Of intense black, is dubbed in roll
OF the thickness of mans wrist from the loBg
time which 1t takes her to complete these arrange
ments, from the manner in which she minces, and
anbles and pays of her prettiest airs, after she has
put on all her charmswe should clearly infer that
dress and personal ornaments occupy the same por-
ton OF her thoughts that they do of the fashionable
women of civilized society,"


young Indian warrior is VIGOROUSLY the most
thorough going heau in the world. Bond street and
Broadway furnish no subjects that will undergo as
much crimpng and confinement to appear in full
dress. We are confident that have observed
such character constantly occupied with his paints
and his pocket glass full three hours, ying on his
colours, and arranging his tresses, and contemplate

progress of his growing attractions. When he has
finished, the proud triumph of irresistible charms
| is IN his eye.-The chiefs and warriors in full

WEST OF THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS.


We have been politely favored by Gen. CLAnxs
of Indian Affairs. with the pernsa OF
a letter, written by Jedediah S Smith, who has been
for several years engaged 10 hunting and trapping
in the Upper Missouri. and who has visited that ex-
tcn.ve barren country OH the West. not here otore
explored. From this letter. written IN plain stylx.
we extract the following. which, trust, will be
found interesting to our readers.


Missouri Republican.


Ny situation has enabled me to collect information
respecting country which has been. measurably.
yelled in obscury. and unknown to the citizens OF
the Unite States. | allude to the country South
Westof the Great Salt Lake, land West Of the Rocky
mountains.


About the 22d of August, 1896. left the great
Salt Lake. accompanied with party of fifteen men,
for the purpose ofexploring the country to the Sout.
West which was then entirely unknown to me- and
of which could obtain satisfactory information.
from the Indians who inhabt the country on its North
East borders. My general course on leaving the
Lake, was S. W. and w. passing the Little Uta
Lake, and ascending Ashey's River. which empties
into it, where we found nation OF Indians, calling
themselves Sumpdch. who were friendly disposed
towards Us. After leaving the Little Uta Lake,
found no further sign Of ,nFalo-here were. howe
yer. few Of the Anteune and Mountain shees, ana
all abundance OF Black Tailed Hares. Leaving
| Ashe,'s River. | passed over range Of mountains.
s. f. and N. ". and struck river, running $. W
which named Adams River. in compliment TO our
| President. The water of t',s river is OF muddy
cast, and somewhat brackish. TIE country is noun
famous to the East, and IN the West arc detach-
ed rocky hills and sandy plains Passing down
this river some distance. fell in with nation ot
Indians, calling themselves Pd Utches. These In
dans. as well as the Sumpatch, robes made Of
rabbit skins; they raise and pumpkins on which
they principally subsst-except few hares, very


little game of any description is to be found About
ten days march further down, the river turns to this
5 Il. where, on the S. w Of it. there is il remas-
kable cave. the entrance to which about ten or hf-
teen feet high and five or six feet in width after
descending about fifteen feet, opens into large and
spacious room, with the roof, walls, and tloor OF
solid rock salt "a niece of which send you, will,
some other articles which will be hereafter descrlb-
ed followed Adams river two days travel fur
ther, where emp,es into the Seeds Keeder. which
| crossed and went a south course down it, through
(, barren, rocky. and mountainous country. La tS
river are manv shoals and rapids. Further down. Il
valley opens. from five to fifteen miles in width. The
land on the river bank is fertile and timbretl. here


found another tribe of Indians. who call themselves
Amnuchcbes. They cultivate the soil, and raise
, corn. beans. pumpkins and melons in abundance,
and also a little wheat and cotton | was now
nearly destitute of horses, and had learned what it
was to do without food therefore concluded to
remain here fifteen days. to recruit my men and IN
the mean time, succeeded in changing my few re-
naming horses, and was enabled purchase others.
| from il party Of runaway Indians. who had stolen
them from the Spanards | here obtained some
information respecting the Spanish country. OBJ.
, tanned two guides recrossed the Seeds keedcr,
and travelled West course fifteen DAYS. over Il
country of complete barrens, and frequently Iron,
morning until night without water. Crossed salt
, plain eight miles wide and twenty long. On the
surface of the ground is crust OF white salt, un-
derneath is layer of yellow sand, and beneath the
sand few inches, the salt again appears The ri-
yer Seeds Keeder have since learned, empties it.
self into the Gufof California. about 80 miles from
the Aminuchehes. and is there called the Colorado


On my arrival in the province of Upper Califor-
mia, was eyed with suspicion, and was compelled.
10 appear in the presence of the Governor, residing


at ST. Diego, from whence, BY the assistance OF some
American gentlemen, (particularly Capt W. II.
Il Cunningham, of the ship Courier, from boston,1 1
ssns euabled to obtain permission TO return with my
men, by the route had come. also obtained
permission TO purchase such supplies as stood IN
need Of. AS the Governor would not permit me
10 travel up the sea coast towards Bodago, pao-
ceeded eastward of the Spanish settlement. then
, turned my course N. W. keeping from so to eco
, miles from the sen coast travelled three hun
, Idred miles in this direction, through country
